The "Business Transparency on Trafficking and Slavery Act" requires disclosure of policies to eradicate slavery and forced labor in supply chains, following California's lead in 2010. The Act addresses the global issue of goods made by forced labor and child labor, emphasizing the importance of human rights impact information for US consumers and investors. The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 allows importation of goods made with forced labor, with exceptions for goods not produced in sufficient quantities in the US.
